overview_content.description: Fundamental Rights are the basic human rights enshrined in the Constitution of India which are guaranteed to all citizens. They are enforceable by the courts, subject to specific restrictions. These rights are crucial for the all-round development of individuals and to preserve human dignity.
overview_content.location_in_constitution: Part III of the Constitution from Articles 12 to 35.
importance: Serve as limitations on government power
Ensure the democratic nature of our polity
Part of the "basic structure" of the Constitution, meaning they cannot be removed even by constitutional amendment

content.definition: Fundamental Rights are basic rights that are guaranteed to all citizens by the Constitution.
key_points: Essential for the all-round development of individuals
Available against the state (with some exceptions that can be enforced against individuals too)

need_for_fundamental_rights.protection_against_state_tyranny: They limit government power and prevent abuse of authority
need_for_fundamental_rights.promotion_of_dignity: They ensure respect for human dignity and worth
need_for_fundamental_rights.establishment_of_democracy: They are essential for a functioning democracy
need_for_fundamental_rights.protection_of_minorities: They safeguard the rights of minority groups
need_for_fundamental_rights.social_transformation: They help in removing social evils like untouchability

constitutional_remedies.description: The right to constitutional remedies (Article 32) allows citizens to approach the Supreme Court directly if their fundamental rights are violated.
constitutional_remedies.alternative: High Courts can also be approached under Article 226

writs_available: Habeas Corpus: To produce a detained person before the court
Mandamus: To order a public authority to perform its duty
Prohibition: To prohibit a lower court from proceeding with a case
Certiorari: To transfer a case from a lower court to a higher court
Quo Warranto: To question the legality of a claim to a public office

content.basic_concept: Article 14 states: "The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India."

components_of_article_14.equality_before_law: This is a negative concept that implies the absence of any special privileges for anyone. All persons are subject to the same laws.

components_of_article_14.equal_protection_of_laws: This is a positive concept that ensures equal treatment in equal circumstances. It permits reasonable classification of persons, objects, and transactions by the state for the purpose of achieving specific ends.

reasonable_classification.definition: For a classification to be reasonable under Article 14, it must satisfy two conditions:
conditions: The classification must be based on an intelligible differentia (some distinguishing feature)
The differentia must have a rational relation to the object sought to be achieved by the law

examples_of_application: Laws providing special protection for women and children
Treating different categories of employees differently based on educational qualifications
Progressive taxation where higher income groups pay higher tax rates
recent_developments: The Supreme Court has evolved the principle of "substantive equality" that goes beyond formal equality
The doctrine of "arbitrariness" where any arbitrary action by the state violates Article 14
The concept that equals should be treated equally and unequals should not be treated equally
landmark_cases: E.P. Royappa v. State of Tamil Nadu (1974)
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978)
Indra Sawhney v. Union of India (1992)

content.basic_concept: Article 15 prohibits discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.

key_provisions.article_15_1: The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them.

key_provisions.article_15_2: No citizen shall be subjected to any disability, liability, restriction or condition with regard to: a) Access to shops, public restaurants, hotels and places of public entertainment b) The use of wells, tanks, bathing ghats, roads and places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public

key_provisions.article_15_3: The State can make special provisions for women and children.

key_provisions.article_15_4: The State can make special provisions for the advancement of socially and educationally backward classes or for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

key_provisions.article_15_5: The State can make special provisions for admission to educational institutions (including private institutions) for backward classes.

key_provisions.article_15_6: The State can make special provisions for economically weaker sections (EWS) of citizens apart from those mentioned in clauses (4) and (5).

examples_of_application: Reservation policies for SC/ST/OBC in educational institutions and government jobs
Special laws for the protection of women and children
Scholarships and educational benefits for backward classes
10% reservation for EWS in the general category
historical_context: Article 15(4) was added by the First Amendment (1951) in response to the Supreme Court's decision in State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan
Article 15(5) was added by the 93rd Amendment (2005) to allow reservations in private educational institutions
Article 15(6) was added by the 103rd Amendment (2019) to provide for EWS reservation
landmark_cases: State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan (1951)
Indra Sawhney v. Union of India (1992)
M. Nagaraj v. Union of India (2006)
EV Chinnaiah v. State of Andhra Pradesh (2004)

content.basic_concept: Article 16 guarantees equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.

key_provisions.article_16_1: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.

key_provisions.article_16_2: No citizen shall be discriminated against in respect of any employment or office under the State on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth, residence or any of them.

key_provisions.article_16_3: Parliament may make laws prescribing residence requirements for certain employments within a state.

key_provisions.article_16_4: The State can make provisions for reservation of appointments or posts in favor of backward classes that are not adequately represented in State services.

key_provisions.article_16_4A: The State can make provisions for reservation in matters of promotion for SC/ST.

key_provisions.article_16_4B: The State can consider unfilled reserved vacancies as a separate class of vacancies to be filled up in succeeding years.

key_provisions.article_16_5: Laws can provide that the incumbent of an office related to religious or denominational institution should belong to that particular religion or denomination.

key_provisions.article_16_6: The State can make provisions for reservation up to 10% for economically weaker sections (EWS) in addition to the existing reservations.

reservation_policy.description: The Supreme Court has capped total reservations at 50% (except in extraordinary situations).
details: Creamy layer concept applies to OBC reservations
No creamy layer concept for SC/ST reservations

examples_of_application: Reservation quotas in public sector jobs
Special recruitment drives for underprivileged sections
Relaxation in age and qualification requirements for certain categories
landmark_cases: Indra Sawhney v. Union of India (1992)
M. Nagaraj v. Union of India (2006)
Jarnail Singh v. Lachhmi Narain Gupta (2018)

content.basic_concept: Article 17 states: 'Untouchability is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of untouchability shall be an offense punishable in accordance with law.'
historical_context: Untouchability has been a social evil in India for centuries.
It involves discrimination against certain castes and treating them as 'impure'.
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, himself born into an 'untouchable' family, played a crucial role in including this provision.
implementation_laws: Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955 (originally named the Untouchability (Offences) Act, 1955)
Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989
The Employment of Manual Scavengers and Construction of Dry Latrines (Prohibition) Act, 1993
Prohibition of Employment as Manual Scavengers and their Rehabilitation Act, 2013
forms_of_untouchability_prohibited: Denial of access to public places, temples, water sources
recent_developments: Supreme Court's active role in enforcing anti-untouchability provisions
Recognition of manual scavenging as a form of untouchability
Increased penalties for untouchability-related offenses
Special courts for speedy trials of such cases
landmark_cases: People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India (1982)
Safai Karamchari Andolan v. Union of India (2014)

content.basic_concept: Article 18 prohibits the state from conferring titles (except military and academic distinctions) and prevents citizens from accepting titles from foreign states without the President's approval.
key_provisions: Article 18(1): No title, not being a military or academic distinction, shall be conferred by the State.
Article 18(2): No citizen of India shall accept any title from any foreign State.
Article 18(3): No person holding any office of profit or trust under the State shall accept any present, emolument, or office from or under any foreign State without the President's consent.
Article 18(4): No person who is not a citizen of India shall accept any title from the State while being a citizen of a foreign state without the President's consent.
historical_context: During British rule, titles like 'Rai Bahadur', 'Sir', etc. were given to create a loyal class.
These titles created artificial distinctions in society.
Article 18 aims to promote a spirit of equality among citizens.
permitted_distinctions: Military distinctions (like Param Vir Chakra, Maha Vir Chakra)
National awards (Bharat Ratna, Padma Vibhushan, etc.) are not considered 'titles' as per Supreme Court.
content.landmark_case: Balaji Raghavan v. Union of India (1996): Supreme Court held that national awards like Bharat Ratna do not amount to 'titles' under Article 18.

content.basic_concept: Article 19(1)(a) guarantees to all citizens the right to freedom of speech and expression. This is considered one of the most essential rights in a democracy.
what_it_includes: Right to express one's convictions and opinions freely
Freedom of press (though not explicitly mentioned)
Right to broadcast information
Right to commercial speech (advertisements)
Right to criticize government policies
Right to silence
Right to information
Right to internet access (as per recent judgments)

reasonable_restrictions.Article_19_2: The state can impose restrictions on this freedom on the following grounds:

recent_developments: Recognition of the right to internet access as part of freedom of speech
Issues related to hate speech on social media
Intermediary liability rules
Regulation of OTT platforms
Protection of journalistic sources
landmark_cases: Romesh Thappar v. State of Madras (1950)
Indian Express Newspapers v. Union of India (1985)
S. Rangarajan v. P. Jagjivan Ram (1989)
Shreya Singhal v. Union of India (2015)
Anuradha Bhasin v. Union of India (2020)

content.basic_concept: Article 19(1)(b) guarantees to all citizens the right to assemble peacefully without arms.
what_it_includes: Right to gather in public places
Right to conduct public meetings
Right to hold demonstrations and processions
Right to form associations or unions

reasonable_restrictions.Article_19_3: This right can be restricted on the grounds of:

rules_governing_assemblies: Section 144 of CrPC allows magistrates to prohibit assemblies
Police regulations requiring prior permission for processions
Restrictions on assemblies near sensitive installations
practical_aspects: Procedure for obtaining permission for public gatherings
Distinction between peaceful assembly and violent mob
Role of police in managing assemblies
landmark_cases: Kameshwar Prasad v. State of Bihar (1962)
Himat Lal K. Shah v. Commissioner of Police (1973)
In Re: Ramlila Maidan Incident (2012)
Anita Thakur v. State of J&K (2016)

content.basic_concept: Article 19(1)(c) guarantees to all citizens the right to form associations or unions.
what_it_includes: Right to form political parties
Right to form trade unions
Right to form companies, societies, partnerships
Right to form clubs and organizations
Right not to join an association

reasonable_restrictions.Article_19_4: This right can be restricted on the grounds of:

related_laws: Representation of People Act (for political parties)
special_provisions: Regulation of foreign funding for associations
landmark_cases: All India Bank Employees Association v. National Industrial Tribunal (1962)
Damyanti v. Union of India (1971)
Indian National Congress (I) v. Institute of Social Welfare (2002)

content.basic_concept: Article 19(1)(d) guarantees the right to move freely throughout the territory of India. Article 19(1)(e) guarantees the right to reside and settle in any part of India.
what_it_includes: Right to travel anywhere within India
Right to settle or reside anywhere in India
Right to return to India (for citizens)
Freedom from unreasonable restrictions on movement

reasonable_restrictions.Article_19_5: These rights can be restricted on the grounds of:
grounds: Protection of interests of Scheduled Tribes

special_provisions: Inner Line Permits for certain Northeastern states
Special provisions for Kashmir, Himachal Pradesh, etc., regarding property purchase
examples_of_application: Removal of travel restrictions between states
Rights of migrant workers to settle in any state
landmark_cases: Kharak Singh v. State of UP (1963)
Satwant Singh Sawhney v. D. Ramarathnam (1967)
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978)

content.basic_concept: Article 19(1)(g) guarantees the right to practice any profession or carry on any occupation, trade, or business.
what_it_includes: Right to choose any profession
Right to establish and run businesses
Right to practice occupation of choice
Right to earn livelihood by legal means

reasonable_restrictions.Article_19_6: This right can be restricted on the grounds of:
grounds: Professional or technical qualifications necessary for practicing a profession

examples_of_reasonable_restrictions: Standards and qualifications for doctors, lawyers, etc.
recent_developments: Recognition of right to dignified livelihood
Regulation of gig economy workers
Licensing reforms for ease of doing business
Recognition of new professions and occupations
landmark_cases: Sodan Singh v. NDMC (1989)
Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation (1985)
Chintaman Rao v. State of MP (1950)
Excel Wear v. Union of India (1978)

content.basic_concept: Article 20 provides three safeguards to persons accused of crimes:

protection_against_ex_post_facto_laws.Article_20_1: No person shall be convicted of any offense except for violation of a law in force at the time of the commission of the act
protection_against_ex_post_facto_laws.penalty: No person shall be subjected to a penalty greater than that prescribed by the law in force at the time of commission of the offense

protection_against_double_jeopardy.Article_20_2: No person shall be prosecuted and punished for the same offense more than once

protection_against_self_incrimination.Article_20_3: No person accused of any offense shall be compelled to be a witness against himself

important_aspects: Article 20 rights are available to both citizens and non-citizens
These rights cannot be suspended even during an emergency
These protections apply only in criminal cases, not civil proceedings
The protection against self-incrimination extends to both oral and documentary evidence
recent_developments: Issues related to narco-analysis, brain mapping, and polygraph tests
DNA testing and biometric evidence
Immunity provisions in new laws
Recording of confessions under special laws
landmark_cases: Selvi v. State of Karnataka (2010)
Nandini Satpathy v. P.L. Dani (1978)
State of Bombay v. Kathi Kalu Oghad (1961)

submodule_13.title: Right to Life and Personal Liberty (Article 21)

content.basic_concept: Article 21 states: 'No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law.'
evolution_of_interpretation: Narrow interpretation in A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras (1950)
Liberal interpretation after Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978)
Now includes various implied rights as part of right to life
rights_included_under_article_21: Right to live with human dignity
Right to health and medical care
Right to legal aid and speedy trial

procedure_established_by_law.initial_interpretation: Initially interpreted as any procedure laid down by statute
procedure_established_by_law.post_maneka_gandhi_case: After Maneka Gandhi case, interpreted to mean 'fair, just and reasonable procedure'
procedure_established_by_law.due_process_concept: Due process concept incorporated through judicial interpretation

landmark_cases: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978)
Francis Coralie Mullin v. Administrator, Union Territory of Delhi (1981)
Olga Tellis v. Bombay Municipal Corporation (1985)
Paschim Banga Khet Mazdoor Samity v. State of West Bengal (1996)
Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017)
Navtej Singh Johar v. Union of India (2018)

content.basic_concept: Article 21A states: 'The State shall provide free and compulsory education to all children of the age of six to fourteen years in such manner as the State may, by law, determine.'
historical_context: Added by the 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002
Shifted education from Directive Principles to Fundamental Rights
Implemented through the Right of Children to Free and Compulsory Education (RTE) Act, 2009
key_features_of_rte_act: Free and compulsory education for all children between 6-14 years
25% reservation in private schools for disadvantaged sections
No capitation fees or screening procedures for admissions
Prohibition of physical punishment and mental harassment
Minimum norms and standards for schools
No detention policy up to class 8
recent_developments: Amendment to allow detention policy after Class 5
Emphasis on learning outcomes
Extension of RTE to early childhood education and secondary education
National Education Policy 2020 implications
landmark_cases: Society for Un-aided Private Schools of Rajasthan v. Union of India (2012)
Pramati Educational and Cultural Trust v. Union of India (2014)
Environmental & Consumer Protection Foundation v. Delhi Administration (2012)

content.basic_concept: Article 22 provides safeguards against arbitrary arrest and detention. It also deals with preventive detention laws.

article_22_1_and_2: Right to be informed of grounds of arrest
Right to consult and be defended by a lawyer of choice
Right to be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours
No detention beyond 24 hours without magistrate's authority

article_22_3: Persons arrested or detained under preventive detention laws

article_22_4_to_7: No preventive detention beyond 3 months without approval of an Advisory Board
Advisory Board must consist of persons qualified to be High Court judges
Grounds of detention must be communicated to the detainee
Detainee must be given earliest opportunity to make representation against detention

preventive_detention_laws: Prevention of Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances Act, 1988
Conservation of Foreign Exchange and Prevention of Smuggling Activities Act, 1974
safeguards_through_judicial_interpretati: Grounds of detention must be specific, not vague
Delay in considering representation violates Article 22
Grounds must be served in a language understood by detainee
All relevant material must be provided to detainee
landmark_cases: A.K. Roy v. Union of India (1982)
Haradhan Saha v. State of West Bengal (1975)
D.K. Basu v. State of West Bengal (1997)

article_23.title: Prohibition of Traffic in Human Beings and Forced Labor
article_23.basic_concept: Article 23 prohibits traffic in human beings, begar (forced labor), and similar forms of forced labor. Any contravention is an offense punishable by law.
what_it_prohibits: Trafficking in human beings: Includes slavery, buying and selling of humans, sexual exploitation, etc.
Begar: Forcing someone to work without payment
Forced labor: Compelling someone to work against their will
Bonded labor: Work in return for paying off a debt
article_23.exception: The State can impose compulsory service for public purposes, but cannot discriminate on grounds of religion, race, caste, or class.
implementation_laws: Trafficking of Persons (Prevention, Protection and Rehabilitation) Bill
landmark_cases: People's Union for Democratic Rights v. Union of India (1982)
Bandhua Mukti Morcha v. Union of India (1984)
Neeraja Chaudhary v. State of MP (1984)

article_24.title: Prohibition of Employment of Children in Factories, etc.
article_24.basic_concept: Article 24 prohibits employment of children below 14 years of age in factories, mines, or any other hazardous employment.
implementation_laws: Child Labour (Prohibition and Regulation) Act, 1986 (amended in 2016)
Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015
key_provisions: Complete prohibition of employment of children below 14 years in all occupations
Prohibition of employment of adolescents (14-18 years) in hazardous occupations
Exception for children helping family after school hours (except hazardous occupations)
Increased penalties for violations
recent_developments: Harmonization with Right to Education Act
National Child Labour Project for rehabilitation
State action plans for elimination of child labor
Skills training for adolescents
landmark_cases: M.C. Mehta v. State of Tamil Nadu (1996)
Bachpan Bachao Andolan v. Union of India (2011)

article_25.title: Freedom of Conscience and Free Profession, Practice and Propagation of Religion
article_25.basic_concept: Article 25 guarantees to all persons freedom of conscience and the right to freely profess, practice, and propagate religion.
restrictions: Other provisions of Part III of the Constitution
Laws regulating economic, financial, political, or secular activity associated with religious practice
Laws providing for social welfare and reform
state_powers: Can regulate secular activities associated with religious practices
Can throw open Hindu religious institutions to all sections of Hindus
Can make laws for social welfare and reform
important_aspects: Includes right to convert but not right to forcible conversion
Applies to both citizens and non-citizens
landmark_cases: Stanislaus v. State of Madhya Pradesh (1977)
Bijoe Emmanuel v. State of Kerala (1986)
Shayara Bano v. Union of India (2017)

article_26.title: Freedom to Manage Religious Affairs
article_26.basic_concept: Article 26 gives every religious denomination or section the right to: Establish and maintain institutions for religious and charitable purposes, manage its own affairs in matters of religion, own and acquire movable and immovable property, and administer such property in accordance with law.
article_26.restrictions: Subject to public order, morality, and health.
key_aspects: Distinction between religious and secular activities
Religious denominations have autonomy in essential religious matters
State can regulate secular activities and financial matters
landmark_cases: Shirur Mutt case (1954)
Durgah Committee v. Hussain Ali (1961)
S.P. Mittal v. Union of India (1983)
Indian Young Lawyers Association v. State of Kerala (Sabarimala case) (2018)

article_27.title: Freedom from Payment of Taxes for Promotion of Any Religion
article_27.basic_concept: Article 27 states that no person shall be compelled to pay any taxes for the promotion or maintenance of any particular religion or religious denomination.
key_aspects: Prohibits state funding for religious promotion
Prohibits use of tax money for religious purposes
Reinforces secular character of the state
Doesn't prohibit general grants to religious institutions for secular purposes
examples_of_application: No state tax can be imposed specifically for religious purposes
Government cannot use tax money to promote a particular religion
Secular purposes like education or healthcare can receive funding regardless of religious management

article_28.title: Freedom from Religious Instruction in Certain Educational Institutions
article_28.basic_concept: Article 28 deals with religious instruction in educational institutions.
key_provisions: No religious instruction shall be provided in institutions wholly maintained out of State funds
Exception: Institutions established under any endowment where religious instruction is required by the terms of the endowment

No person attending any educational institution recognized by the State or receiving State aid shall be required to participate in religious instruction or worship without consent (or guardian's consent for minors)
implications: No restriction on unaided private institutions

article_29.title: Protection of Interests of Minorities
article_29.basic_concept: Article 29 protects the language, script, and culture of minorities.
key_provisions: Any section of citizens with a distinct language, script, or culture has the right to conserve the same
No citizen shall be denied admission to any educational institution maintained or aided by the State on grounds only of religion, race, caste, language, or any of them
important_aspects: Protection not limited to religious minorities but extends to linguistic and cultural minorities
Applies to both minorities and majority groups with distinct culture
Prevents discrimination in admissions to state-funded educational institutions
landmark_cases: State of Madras v. Champakam Dorairajan (1951)
St. Stephen's College v. University of Delhi (1992)

article_30.title: Right of Minorities to Establish and Administer Educational Institutions
article_30.basic_concept: Article 30 gives religious and linguistic minorities the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice.
key_provisions: All minorities, whether based on religion or language, have the right to establish and administer educational institutions of their choice
The State shall not discriminate against any educational institution managed by a minority while granting aid

In making any law providing for the compulsory acquisition of property of an educational institution established and administered by a minority, the State shall ensure that the compensation amount fixed doesn't restrict or abrogate this right
important_aspects: Recognition of minority status determined by state or national level
Includes right to choose management, teachers, staff, students
Right to set medium of instruction
landmark_cases: St. Xavier's College v. State of Gujarat (1974)
TMA Pai Foundation v. State of Karnataka (2002)
P.A. Inamdar v. State of Maharashtra (2005)
Society for Unaided Private Schools v. Union of India (2012)

content.basic_concept: Article 32 provides the right to approach the Supreme Court directly for enforcement of Fundamental Rights. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar called it 'the heart and soul of the Constitution.'
key_provisions: Right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of Fundamental Rights
Supreme Court's power to issue directions, orders, or writs for enforcement of Fundamental Rights
Parliament can empower any other court to issue writs without affecting the Supreme Court's powers
This right cannot be suspended except as provided by the Constitution

habeas_corpus.purpose: To release a person who has been unlawfully detained
habeas_corpus.scope: Available against both public authorities and private individuals
habeas_corpus.key_feature: Can be filed by any person, not just the detainee

mandamus.purpose: To order a public authority to perform its public duty
mandamus.scope: Issued against public officials, government, corporations, or lower courts
mandamus.key_feature: Not issued against private individuals or the President/Governors

prohibition.purpose: To prohibit a lower court from proceeding with a case beyond its jurisdiction
prohibition.scope: Preventive in nature, issued during pendency of proceedings
prohibition.key_feature: Only against judicial or quasi-judicial authorities

certiorari.purpose: To quash orders of lower courts or tribunals that have acted beyond jurisdiction
certiorari.scope: Corrective in nature, issued after the order has been passed
certiorari.key_feature: Can review issues of jurisdiction and errors of law apparent on record

quo_warranto.purpose: To question the legality of a claim to a public office
quo_warranto.scope: Against public offices of substantive nature created by statute or constitution
quo_warranto.key_feature: Can be filed by any person, even if not personally aggrieved

article_32.description: Can be invoked only for enforcement of Fundamental Rights

article_226.description: Can be invoked for any legal right, not just Fundamental Rights

supreme_court.article_32: Supreme Court cannot refuse to entertain petitions under Article 32
supreme_court.article_226: High Courts have wider discretion under Article 226

landmark_cases: Bandhua Mukti Morcha v. Union of India (1984)
S.P. Gupta v. Union of India (1982)
L. Chandra Kumar v. Union of India (1997)
A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras (1950)

content.basic_concept: Fundamental Rights in India are not absolute and are subject to reasonable restrictions imposed by the state.

examples: Restrictions based on basic structure doctrine

restrictions_during_emergency.article_358: Suspension of Article 19 during national emergency
restrictions_during_emergency.article_359: Suspension of enforcement of specified Fundamental Rights during emergency
restrictions_during_emergency.exception: No suspension of Articles 20 and 21 during any emergency

doctrine_of_reasonable_restrictions.description: Reasonable restrictions must satisfy specific criteria.
criteria: Must be proportionate to the need
Must not be arbitrary or excessive

factors: Extent and urgency of the evil sought to be remedied

developments: Proportionality test in restricting Fundamental Rights
Greater scrutiny for restrictions on Articles 14, 19, and 21

landmark_cases: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973)
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India (1978)
Modern Dental College v. State of MP (2016)
K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India (2017)
